column1: The Main  (German pronunciation: [ˈmaɪn] (listen)) is the longest tributary of the Rhine. It rises as the White Main in the Fichtel Mountains of northeastern Bavaria and flows west through central Germany for 525 kilometres (326 mi) to meet the Rhine below Russelsheim
column2: Hesse. The cities of Mainz and Wiesbaden are close to the confluence.

column1: The largest cities on the Main are Frankfurt am Main
column2: Offenbach am Main and Würzburg. It is the longest river lying entirely in Germany (if the Weser-Werra are considered separate).

column1: == Geography ==
The Main flows through the north and north-west of the state of Bavaria then across southern Hesse; against the latter it demarcates a third state
column3: east and west of Wertheim am Main
column4: the northernmost town of that state.

column1: The upper end of its basin opposes that of the Danube where the watershed is recognised by natural biologists
column2: sea salinity studies (and hydrology science more broadly) as the European Watershed.

column1: The Main begins near Kulmbach in Franconia at the joining of its two headstreams
column2: the Red Main (Roter Main) and the White Main (Weißer Main).  The Red Main originates in the Franconian Jura mountain range
column4: and runs through Creussen and Bayreuth. The White Main originates in the mountains of the Fichtelgebirge; it is 41 km (25 mi) long. In its upper and middle section
column5: the Main runs through the valleys of the German Highlands. Its lower section crosses the Lower Main Lowlands (Hanau-Seligenstadt Basin and northern Upper Rhine Plain) to Wiesbaden
column6: where it discharges into the Rhine. Major tributaries of the Main are the Regnitz
column9: and the Nidda.The name "Main" derives from the Latin Moenus or Menus. It is not related to the name of the city Mainz (Latin: Moguntiacum).

column1: == Navigation ==
The Main is navigable for shipping from its mouth at the Rhine close to Mainz for 396 km (246 mi) to Bamberg. Since 1992
column2: the Main has been connected to the Danube via the Rhine-Main-Danube Canal and the highly regulated Altmühl river. The Main has been canalized with 34 large locks (300 × 12 m or 984 × 39 ft) to allow CEMT class V vessels (110 × 11.45 m or 360.9 × 37.6 ft) to navigate the total length of the river. The 16 locks in the adjacent Rhine-Main-Danube Canal and the Danube itself are of the same dimensions.

column1: == Main line ==
In a historical and political sense
column2: the Main line is referred to as the northern border of Southern Germany
column3: with its predominantly Catholic population. The river roughly marked the southern border of the North German Federation
column4: established in 1867 under Prussian leadership as the predecessor of the German Empire.

column1: The river course also corresponds with the Speyer line isogloss between Central and Upper German dialects
== Recreation ==
The Main-Radweg is a major German bicycle path alongside the river. Approximately 600 kilometres long (370 mi)
column2: it is the first long-distance instance awarded 5 stars by the General German Bicycle Club (ADFC) in 2008.  It starts from Creußen or Bischofsgrün and ends in Mainz.
